div.head: Current position
div.p: Lou Burnard Consulting specialises in research applications of text encoding in literature and linguistics, working mostly but not exclusively in France. Between 2011 and 2015 I provided TEI consultancy services to the TGE Adonis (precursor of Huma-Num) and worked with many digital projects in France, before setting up as an independent consultant.

Before taking early retirement in 2010, I was Assistant Director of Oxford University Computing Services. Reporting to the Director of OUCS, my responsibilities included policy development, budgetary control, and strategic planning for the department, which was responsible for provision of key IT services across the University. I managed over 25 staff in the largest of the four groups into which OUCS was divided, comprising the Research Technologies Service, the Integrated Help Centre, and Information Services section. I represented the department on several University and college committees. I was responsible for several international research projects, notably the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI), and the continued management of the British National Corpus project.

div.head: Research experience
div.p: TEI (Text Encoding Initiative) P5 Release. Principal Editor and designer of the most recent major revision of the TEI Guidelines. See . I have twice been elected to the TEI Board, and was charged with providing editorial support to the TEI Council 2007-2010. After that date I was regularly elected to the Technical Council, until 2016 when I decided to stand down.

list.head: Funded research projects
list.item: I am one of two UK representatives on the COST Action CA 16204, "Distant Reading for European Literary History", with particular responsibility for Work Group 1 (Scholarly Resources) activities, notably the design and implementation of the "European Literary Text Collection" (ELTeC) corpus: see further

item.p: I was responsible for OUCS deliverables for the ENRICH project, which developed a TEI P5-conformant metadata standard for major European manuscript cataloguing project, funded 2007-9 under the EU Contentplus Programme. See

XAIRA (XML Aware Indexing and Retrieval Architecture) : an advanced text-searching software system for XML resources, funded by the Mellon Foundation between 2005-6 and subsequently an open source project (see ) .
Textometrie: I was the sole British member of this ANR-funded project at the ENS-LSH in Lyon when it was initiated. (see ).

MASTER (Manuscript access through standards for electronic records): Funded 1998-2001 under the EU Libraries Programme, this project devised and tested an XML standard for the detailed description of manuscripts. I was responsible for development and maintenance of the standard, and associated software.

Memoria: I was a partner in this EU funded digital library, producing several working papers on delivery mechanisms for textual material in collaboration with the Bibliotheque Nationale de France (1994-5)

AHDS Feasibility Study: Together with Harold Short (Kings College London) I carried out the detailed feasibility study which led to the establishment by the JISC of the Arts and Humanities Data Service (1994-5)

BNC (British National Corpus): This 100 million word corpus of British English, both spoken and written, was created by an academic/industrial consortium with joint DTI/SERC funding between 1990-1994. I was responsible for Oxford University's participation in the project, in particular the design of its encoding scheme and management of the local development team, and remain responsible for maintenance and worldwide distribution of the corpus. A second edition was published in 2001; and a third, with major revisions, appeared in March 2007.

TEI (Text Encoding Initiative): The TEI was set up as an international project to develop methods for the encoding and interchange of machine-readable texts intended for literary, linguistic, historical, or other textual research in 1988 with funding from the US National Endowment for the Humanities, the Canadian Social Science Research Council, the Mellon Foundation, and the EU Language Engineering Programme. I was appointed TEI European Editor in 1989, and have been a key figure in the establishment and development of the standard ever since, participating in a very wide range of teaching and advisory activities, working with many scholars and experts worldwide.

I have designed and taught many TEI training courses, ranging in length from a day to a week, for both beginning and advanced students. Examples include introductory courses sponsored annually since 2007 by the CESR, University of Tours, and a two-level course first organised for the Ecole Nationale des Chartes in 2011 and 2012. I have also taught shorter more specialised training workshop sessions on such topics as corpus design and construction, linguistic annotation, transcription of speech, and TEI customization, as well as generic introductions to the TEI tailored to the interest of a particular institution or research group.
